Author: ComputerGenie 游놊游낖游닉#7004
Content: `rpcworkqueue` = the queue length for rpc work

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: So there is no rate limit on how many requests I can send to the network? i.e. Am I rate limited on how frequently I can create orders?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: one per second

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: Is this to prevent the network from being flooded? Or for something else?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: spam prevention can be enabled

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is just set on the minimum setting now but PoW for each packet can be changed with a #define

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also there are 14000+ different netids, each a totally independent networl

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: What do you mean by "PoW for each packet" @jl777c

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: Also, could you please tag me in responses if possible? I am using discord in browser so it's much easier to respond if I get a notification

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @wbradt each packet would do some PoW to be valid

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: Sorry, I do not quite understand this. What PoW is being done? Doesn't PoW require computational resources? Whose are used? How is a packet "valid"--or rather how would one be invalid? @jl777c

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
@wbradt each packet would do some PoW to be valid
any PoW that takes computational resources will force the sender to spend resources and thus make spam more expensive to do

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: packet would be considered valid based on the PoW rules, whatever they are. I used the standard leading 0 bits

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but it can be like txpow, generate txids until first and last bytes are 0, then it would limit to once per 20 seconds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so a bit too much PoW

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: Ok, I understand. So is the POW constant for all users? So it takes less time for a node with a "faster" computer to create orders?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @wbradt it would need to be a network wide rule. yes, faster nodes could make more orders

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: I think I may have misunderstood: Is requiring PoW to send a message (or "validate a packet") in place (or "a rule") on the main BarterDEX network? @jl777c

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i remember i had it in place, but set it to minimum work, so it only takes a few millliseconds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not hard to add/change

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: Is the 1-second request limit in place? @jl777c

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: each request needs a unique timestamp, which has 1 second resolution

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: Great. Thanks for the help.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: are you with some project @wbradt

Author: wbradt#2043
Content:
Not really. I developed some market making algos last year 
 (https://github.com/wardbradt/peregrine) and was thinking of incorporating BarterDEX. I have more become generally interested in how BarterDEX works. @jl777c

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
@jl777c @artem.pikulin @artemciy_dice are any of you familiar with this: https://github.com/GuggerJoel/XMR-BTC-atomic/blob/master/whitepaper/xmr-btc.pdf

Do you think it would be feasible to implement in mm?

I think the first practical BTC <-> XMR atomic swap implementation would be pretty big news.

I thought XMR needed more features added to be able to implement atomic swaps but this whitepaper seems to imply it can be achieved using just multisig on the XMR end.

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: @lukechilds Hi, I see this whitepaper 1st time. It looks similar to old swap protocol that was used in MM1, Hash/time locked txs on BTC side and multisig on XMR. It's possible to add/reimplement this in MM2, however there were no requests to add XMR previously.

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
Yeah, possibly for political reasons? Because Zcash and Monero are somewhat rivals and Komodo is a Zcash fork, Komodo members are more likely to be interested in Zcash as a privacy coin than Monero. So that could explain why there hasn't been much demand for Monero from within the Komodo community.

But I think this could be more of a publicity stunt that could bring a lot of attention from people outside of the current community. The Monero community has wanted atomic swaps with Bitcoin for a very long time. A working implementation of this that people can test out would be big news and hopefully get some well deserved publicity for Komodo.

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: But I'm assuming it would be quite a bit of work to implement so obviously you'd need to weigh up if it's worth implementing over other stuff you're working on

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: Also, due to the private nature of Monero, it's very popular on decentralised exchanges, BTC/XMR is the highest volume pair on Bisq. It could bring in some much needed liquidity

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: I'm not involved in any political discussions. Didn't ever see that XMR is not allowed to be mentioned here. From developer point of view it's possible to integrate. However it might be hard to support different swap protocol for every coin. Also it might confuse the user, e.g. `Why do I need to have 2 BTC to sell only 1 for XMR?`.

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: We can discuss it later if there's a demand from `users` to add XMR or any other coin.

Author: KomodoWorld#8282
Content: I remember many people asking for XMR, also ptyx or someone else approached fluffypony but XMR devs were not interested to collaborate

Author: KomodoWorld#8282
Content: or so I read

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: @KomodoWorld Thanks for the info!

Author: cipi#4502
Content:
not really... besides making sure the config file has the same name as the datadir
`~/.electra/electra.conf` and not `~/.electra/Electra.conf` or something else...

Author: cipi#4502
Content: if the config file has the same name, confpath is not needed and everything works fine

Author: cipi#4502
Content: in Linux i made a symlink to correct this: `cd ~/.electra && ln -s electra.conf Electra.conf`

Author: DRE#7875
Content: @cipi where i can find electra.conf in barterdex

Author: cipi#4502
Content: electra.conf is the config file of the wallet... it is located in the datadir, where wallet.dat and blockchain-data is also located

Author: cipi#4502
Content: i would change the code of the daemon, so that the config file is named `electra.conf` and not `Electra.conf`

Author: DRE#7875
Content: electra.conf

Author: cipi#4502
Content: content looks good, but i would set a rpc password... not sure if it works without

Author: DRE#7875
Content: @cipi okay i will try i changed the name it was with big E

Author: cipi#4502
Content: if you just rename the file, it will not work, because the wallet expects the file to be named Electra.conf... this must be changed in the code

Content: rpcpassword needs to be defined if i remember correctly

Content:
coins/coins has
```JSON
"confpath": "USERHOME/.electra/Electra.conf"
```
so, I'm thinking `E` will be needed because js is case-sensitive, no?

Content: its normal, with big E

Content: yes, because confpath is evaluated correctly under Linux, but not in Windows

Author: cipi#4502
Content: but if the file is calles electra.conf, confpath can be removed

Author: cipi#4502
Content: yes... if the wallet would use electra.conf, confpath can be removed from the barterdex config... it is the best solution

Author: cipi#4502
Content: i can also remove confpath from coin database for ECA and let the people deal with it... either the devs correct this in the code, or the users make symlinks

Author: DRE#7875
Content: So to understand, I change nothing in Electra folder and remove only the electra path in BarterDex coin?

Author: cipi#4502
Content: yes, if you remove confpath and the config file is called electra.conf, it will work... even under Windows

Author: cipi#4502
Content:
`"name": "electra"` is the paramater that normally tells BarterDEX where to find the config
it is `~/.$name/$name.conf`

Author: DRE#7875
Content:
thank you, sorry for my english,

so I changed the Electra.conf to electra.conf in appdata and now change the line "confpath" in BarterDex Coin: "USERHOME / .electra / Electra.conf" to "confpath": "

Author: cipi#4502
Content: remove the line confpath completely...

Author: cipi#4502
Content: but as i said: the wallet expects the file to be named Electra.conf... it must be either corrected in the source code of the wallet or you will have to make a symlink electra.conf -> Electra.conf

Author: cipi#4502
Content: or make a copy... so that you have 2 files with the same content, one named `electra.conf` and the other `Electra.conf`

Author: cipi#4502
Content: but best is to fix this in the source code of the wallet, so that it uses `electra.conf`
